guide.introduction:
I wanted to spread the Maker philosophy in my area and thought it may be a good idea to start with a one-day workshop for kids - ArtBots! was the result.

This will cover the basics of what you will need, ideas of where you might source the materials and an outline for running the workshop itself. I have only done this once myself so I am very open to the ideas of others of how to improve it and what I can do to build on its success.
guide.introduction_rendered:
I wanted to spread the Maker philosophy in my area and thought it may be a good idea to start with a one-day workshop for kids - ArtBots! was the result.

This will cover the basics of what you will need, ideas of where you might source the materials and an outline for running the workshop itself. I have only done this once myself so I am very open to the ideas of others of how to improve it and what I can do to build on its success.

Relevant parts
  • Old VCRS
  • Old Cell Phones
  • Dr Scholls Foot Massager
  • Zip ties
  • Rubber bands
  • floor scrub brushes
  • duct tape, electrical tape
Tools
  • Dremel tool with cuttigng, grinding, or routing bits
  • Heat gun
  • Hot Glue gun & hot glue
  • Safety glasses
  • Safety gloves
  • Screwdriver, small, Phillips
  • Soldering iron

parts.notes: great, large vibro motor, switch and battery case
cheap ones found in dollar stores

lines.text: Sand the paint off the tin, if you wish.
lines.text_raw: Sand the paint off the tin, if you wish.

lines.text: Punch 2 holes through the bottom of the tin, one on either end, using a hammer and a Phillips screwdriver. You’ll use these holes to attach the legs.
lines.text_raw: Punch 2 holes through the bottom of the tin, one on either end, using a hammer and a Phillips screwdriver. You’ll use these holes to attach the legs.

lines.text: Punch a hole through the lid near one end. This hole is for routing the wires.
lines.text_raw: Punch a hole through the lid near one end. This hole is for routing the wires.

lines.text: Snip off 2 long pieces of wire from a coat hanger and bend each into a V-shape.
lines.text_raw: Snip off 2 long pieces of wire from a coat hanger and bend each into a V-shape.

lines.text: Bend the tip of the V into a right angle, and then bend a little “foot” at each end.
lines.text_raw: Bend the tip of the V into a right angle, and then bend a little “foot” at each end.

lines.text: Attach the legs to the holes in the tin using bolts, nuts, and metal washers.
lines.text_raw: Attach the legs to the holes in the tin using bolts, nuts, and metal washers.

lines.text: Add a dollop of hot glue to each foot to give them rubber tips.
lines.text_raw: Add a dollop of hot glue to each foot to give them rubber tips.

lines.text: Push a paper clip through one of the plastic flat washers, and attach the washer to the spindle of the motor.
lines.text_raw: Push a paper clip through one of the plastic flat washers, and attach the washer to the spindle of the motor.

lines.text: Solder 2 wires to the 1.5V battery, insert the battery in the candy tin, and thread both wires through the hole in the lid.
lines.text_raw: Solder 2 wires to the 1.5V battery, insert the battery in the candy tin, and thread both wires through the hole in the lid.

lines.text: Solder one wire to a lead on the motor, and solder a third loose wire to the other motor lead.
lines.text_raw: Solder one wire to a lead on the motor, and solder a third loose wire to the other motor lead.

lines.text: Put 2 plastic flat washers between the motor and the candy tin, and secure the motor to the tin using a cable tie.
lines.text_raw: Put 2 plastic flat washers between the motor and the candy tin, and secure the motor to the tin using a cable tie.

lines.text: To operate the Vibrobot, twist the loose battery wire and the loose motor wire together (you can also solder an alligator clip to one of the wires for a switch).
lines.text_raw: To operate the Vibrobot, twist the loose battery wire and the loose motor wire together (you can also solder an alligator clip to one of the wires for a switch).

lines.text: Experiment with the critter by gently bending the paper clip and legs into different shapes and observing the effects.
lines.text_raw: Experiment with the critter by gently bending the paper clip and legs into different shapes and observing the effects.

lines.text: Watch a video at http://www.makezine.com/10/123_vibrobot.
lines.text_raw: Watch a video at http://www.makezine.com/10/123_vibrobot.

steps.title: Check the contents of your kit.

lines.text: You should have 4 toothbrushes, 4 tiny motors with wires attached, 4 batteries with wires attached, and 2 pieces of double-sided tape.
lines.text_raw: You should have 4 toothbrushes, 4 tiny motors with wires attached, 4 batteries with wires attached, and 2 pieces of double-sided tape.

lines.text: Use strong scissors or diagonal cutters to cut the toothbrush head off the handle. Make sure to cut it close to the bristles, as shown here.
lines.text_raw: Use strong scissors or diagonal cutters to cut the toothbrush head off the handle. Make sure to cut it close to the bristles, as shown here.

lines.text: Use scissors to cut one piece of double-sided foam tape into 4 smaller squares.
lines.text_raw: Use scissors to cut one piece of double-sided foam tape into 4 smaller squares.

lines.text: Cut the battery wires about 1" long.
lines.text_raw: Cut the battery wires about 1" long.

lines.text: Then use wire strippers to strip about 1/4" of insulation off the end of each wire.
lines.text_raw: Then use wire strippers to strip about 1/4" of insulation off the end of each wire.

lines.text: The battery has a natural "curve" to it. This curve should be bent upward, to allow the battery to sit flat on the toothbrush.
lines.text_raw: The battery has a natural "curve" to it. This curve should be bent upward, to allow the battery to sit flat on the toothbrush.

lines.text: Use a small square of double-sided foam tape to attach the battery to the toothbrush head.
lines.text_raw: Use a small square of double-sided foam tape to attach the battery to the toothbrush head.

lines.text: Peel the sticker off the motor, and stick the motor firmly on top of the battery.
lines.text_raw: Peel the sticker off the motor, and stick the motor firmly on top of the battery.

lines.text: When you're ready to run your BrushBot, twist each battery lead together with a motor lead to connect them. (The polarity doesn't matter, so you can twist black to black, or black to red.) Your BrushBot will start vibrating!
lines.text_raw: When you're ready to run your BrushBot, twist each battery lead together with a motor lead to connect them. (The polarity doesn't matter, so you can twist black to black, or black to red.) Your BrushBot will start vibrating!

lines.text: Let go and watch it run around!
lines.text_raw: Let go and watch it run around!

lines.text: After you build your BrushBots, mod them for more fun!
lines.text_raw: After you build your BrushBots, mod them for more fun!

lines.text: Connect 2 bots together with tape or a bit of wire.
lines.text_raw: Connect 2 bots together with tape or a bit of wire.

lines.text: Trim or bend the bristles to make the BrushBot change direction.
lines.text_raw: Trim or bend the bristles to make the BrushBot change direction.

lines.text: Add stabilizing wire legs. This way the BrushBots can crash into each other without tipping over.
lines.text_raw: Add stabilizing wire legs. This way the BrushBots can crash into each other without tipping over.

lines.text: Make up a racetrack and see whose BrushBot wins!
lines.text_raw: Make up a racetrack and see whose BrushBot wins!

guide.summary: A guide to setting up, gathering materials and facilitating a One-Day ArtBot class for young people. Each kid will walk away with one creative ArtBot [vibro/brush bot] of their own making and a taste of the Maker World.
guide.time_required: This is planned as a full day workshop but could be shortened.
guide.title: ArtBot Class to introduce kids to Makerdom
